Modulating the ordinary nitrogen coordination environment of single-atom catalysts (SACs) is a promising strategy for customizing their activity and selectivity in electrochemical reduction of CO2 (CO2RR). However, less attention has been paid to developing Mn-SACs with nitrogen-free coordination environment for CO2 electroreduction. Herein, we construct a Mn SAC with a coordination structure of Mn-O4 anchored in nitrogen-doped graphitic carbon, which exhibits a 98.5 % of CO faradic efficiency (FECO) with a high CO partial current density (j CO) of ∼9.77 mA cm−2 at a low overpotential of 0.32 V in an H-type electrolytic cell. Furthermore, a higher current density of 27.8 mA cm−2 with a FECO of 93.8 % at 0.51 V overpotential was achieved in an ionic liquid (IL) electrolyte. Density functional theory (DFT) calculations reveal that the Mn-O4 site significantly lowers the free energy of the COOH* formation compared to the conventional N atoms coordinated Mn SACs, and thus facilitates the CO2-to-CO conversion. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Nitrogen-free Mn-o4 coordination environment Single-atom Mn CO2 reduction Electrocatalysis, Carbon monoxide Data availability Data will be made available on request. Introduction Electrochemical conversion of carbon dioxide (CO2) is one of the cleanest and most promising strategies for both relieving greenhouse gas emissions and producing useful fuels[1–6]. Obviously, novel electrocatalysts with high Faradaic efficiency (FE), large current density and low overpotential of target products were strongly desirable[7,8]. Among these products from CO2 reduction, carbon monoxide (CO) is one of the most important and desirable targets, because it can be utilized as a feedstock for the synthesis of hydrocarbons and alcohol through a Fischer–Tropsch process[9–19]. Thus far, numerous noble metal-based (such as Au, Ag, Pd etc.) electrocatalysts were developed for electrochemical CO2RR, which showed good activity in transforming CO2 into CO at low overpotentials[20–27]. Nevertheless, the prohibitive cost and scarcity of these noble metals seriously limit their large-scale application in electrochemical CO2RR. Hence, developing efficient electrocatalysts based on abundant and cost-effective metals for CO2RR holds great value for practical implementation. Manganese (Mn) holds the distinction of being the third most prevalent transition metal in the natural environment. Therefore, electrocatalysts consisting of Mn are more attractive, and a series of Mn-based electrocatalysts for CO2RR were reported, including Mn complexes[28], Mn oxides[29], Mn single-atom catalysts (SACs)[30–32] etc. Among these catalysts, Mn SACs especially N atom coordinate Mn SACs display a promising application in electrochemical CO2RR, attributing to their peculiar electronic and well-defined structures[30,31]. For instance, the halogen and nitrogen dual-coordinated Mn SAC (Mn-N4Cl) shows a CO faradaic efficiency (FECO) of 97 % at a overpotential of 0.49 V with a current density of ∼10 mA cm−2 [30]. Subsequently, Zhang et al. reported a Mn-N3 SAC inlaid in graphitic carbon nitride exhibiting a FECO of 97 % at 0.44 V overpotential[31]. Recently, Zhang et al. reported the nonnitrogen coordination environment of Sn-SACs is more beneficial for CO2-to-CO conversion than the Sn-N4 site[33]. Inspired by these above results, the nonnitrogen-coordinated Mn-SACs may show considerable efficiency in CO2RR, however, less attention has been paid to constructing Mn-SACs with nitrogen-free coordination environment for electrochemical CO2RR[34]. Herein, we report a Mn SAC featuring a Mn-O4 site embedded in N-doped graphitic carbon (Mn/NCCl) for efficient electrocatalysis CO2RR. As an electrocatalyst, Mn/NCCl exhibits a high CO faradic efficiency (FECO) of 98.5 % at a low overpotential of 0.32 V with a CO partial current density (j CO) of ∼9.77 mA cm−2. In an IL electrolyte, a higher current density of 27.8 mA cm−2 with a FECO of 93.8 % at 0.51 V overpotential could be achieved. DFT calculations reveal that the O atoms coordinated Mn SACs favor *COOH intermediate with lower Gibbs free energy than the Mn SACs with N atoms coordination, resulting in lowering the overpotential of CO2RR, and thus boost the CO2-to-CO conversion. Experimental section Materials 2-Ethylimidazole (>99.0 %), Mn(NO3)2·4H2O (99.0 %), methanol (>99.5 %), Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (>99.0 %), potassium chloride (KCl, >99.5 %), potassium fluoride (KF, >99.5 %), potassium bromide (KBr, >99.5 %) and potassium iodide (KI, >99.5 %) were purchased from Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd.. [Bmim][BF4] (1-Butyl-3-methylimidazolium tetrafluoroborate, >99 %) was purchased from Shanghai Chengjie Co., Ltd.. All chemicals in this work were used as received without further purification. Synthesis of ZIF-8 ZIF-8 is synthesized as previous reports with some modifications[35]. Typically, 2-methylimidazole (6.702 g) was dissolved in 100 mL of methanol. And another 100 mL of methanol containing 5.95 g of Zn(NO3)2·6H2O was added into the pre-prepared 2-methylimidazole solution under vigorous stirring for 4 h, and the well-mixed solution was then aged for 24 h at room temperature to generate ZIF-8. The obtained ZIF-8 was filtered, washed with methanol for several times, and dried in vacuum at 65 °C overnight. Synthesis of Mn/NC-Cl, Mn/NC-f, Mn/NC-Br, Mn/NC-I and Mn/NC Typically, 200 mg of ZIF-8 was first dissolved in 15 mL of methanol. Then 1000 μl (0.1 g/mL) of Mn(NO3)2·4H2O aqueous solution was added to the above pre-prepared solution and stirred for 4 h at room temperature. After reaction, the resulting product was centrifugated and washed by methanol, thus dried in vacuum at 65 °C overnight. The obtained precursor and 100 mg of potassium chloride were annealed at 900 °C for 4 h with a heating rate of 5 °C min−1 under N2 flow. After cooling down to room temperature, the calcined product was washed with HCl for several times to obtain the Mn/CNCl (Fig. 1a ). The Mn/NC-F, Mn/NC-Br and Mn/NC-I were synthesized through the same procedure except that the potassium chloride was substituted by potassium fluoride (80 mg), potassium bromide (160 mg) and potassium iodide (220 mg), respectively. The Mn/NC was prepared via similar procedures except without the addition of potassium chloride. Synthesis of NC For the synthesis of NC, 200 mg of ZIF-8 was annealed at 900 °C for 4 h with a rapping rate of 5 °C min−1 under N2 flow. After cooling down to room temperature, the NC was obtained via leaching the resulting product with HCl to remove the free metal residues. Results and discussion Synthesis and structural characterizations of Mn/NCCl. Mn/NCCl was prepared through thermal pyrolysis of manganese nitrate and pre-formed ZIF-8 metal-organic frameworks (synthesizing according to the reported methods, details were provided in the supporting information) with the assistance of potassium chloride (KCl) under nitrogen at 900 °C (Fig. 1a). Scanning and transmission electron microscope (SEM, TEM) images show the formation of 2D amorphous carbon layered sheet structure (Fig. 1b-d). And no particles were observed on the carbon layer in TEM images. Energy dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDS) images indicate that Mn, O, N, and C distribute homogeneously over the entire surface of Mn/NCCl (Fig. 1f). For comparison, Mn-NC and NC were prepared via same procedures as Mn/NCCl except for the ellipsis of KCl and manganese nitrate, respectively. As shown in Fig. S1, the morphology of NC was almost identical with the Mn/NCCl, while the Mn/NC showed a three-dimensional structure. These results suggest that the chloride-assisted calcination strategy could transform the ZIF-8 to a 2D irregular layered sheet structure, which results in a higher degree of defective carbon and richer catalyst surface exposure. This morphological transformation contributes to the exposure of more active sites, which is beneficial for the CO2RR. Only diffraction peaks at 42° and 25° attributing to the (100) and (002) planes of graphitic carbon were detected from the X-ray diffraction (XRD) pattern of Mn/NCCl and NC (Fig. 1e), suggesting that there are no metal nanoparticles or clusters, which agrees well with the results of the TEM measurements. The HAADF-STEM image verifies the existence of atomically dispersed Mn on Mn/NCCl (Fig. 1 g), and the content of Mn is 0.1 wt% measured by inductively coupled plasma atomic emission spectroscopy (ICP-AES) (Table S1). In addition, the specific surface area of Mn/NCCl (2172.3 m2 g − 1) is much larger than that of Mn/NC (1372.5 m2 g − 1) and NC (759.6 m2 g − 1), which suggests that the chloride-assisted calcination strategy can efficiently increase the surface area (Fig. S2 and Table S2). The chemical composition and valence states of Mn/NCCl and NC were examined by XPS (X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy). The full XPS survey of Mn/NCCl confirms the existence of Mn, O, N and C (Fig. S3). The high-resolution N 1s XPS spectrum shows four peaks at 398.6, 400.7, 401.5 and 403.2 eV, which are corresponded to pyridine nitrogen, pyrrole nitrogen, graphite nitrogen and NO groups on the surface of NC, respectively (Fig. 2a and 2b) [36,37]. The O 1 s XPS spectrum reveals two O species, including Mn-O groups at 529.9 eV and CO groups at 531.6 eV (Fig. 2a and 2c). Comparing to the O 1 s XPS spectrum of NC (Fig. S4), a new signal assigned to the Mn-O groups appeared with the percentage of C = O decreases to 0 %, which indicated that C = O group is highly probable to provide coordination sites for Mn atoms to form Mn-Ox species. The peak located at 641.1 eV is observed in the Mn 2p3/2 XPS spectrum for Mn/NCCl, indicating that the Mn valence state of Mn/NCCl is probably to be +2 (Fig. S5) [38]. To further investigate the local structural information of Mn/NCCl at the atomic level, XAS (X-ray absorption spectroscopy) was conducted. As shown in the XANES (X-ray absorption near-edge structure) spectra of Mn K-edge, the shape of the adsorption curve of Mn/NCCl is close to that of MnO, positioned between Mn3O4 and Mn foil, demonstrating that the Mn valence state of Mn/NCCl is close to +2, which agrees well with the results of Mn 2p XPS (Fig. 2d) [39]. The FT (phase-uncorrected Fourier transform) of the EXAFS (extended X-ray absorption fine structure) spectra for Mn/NCCl in R space shows the main peak at 1.7 Å, matching the Mn-O scattering path, which harmonizes with the O 1 s XPS data (Fig. 2c and 2e). It is noteworthy that, the peak at around 2.3 Å belonging to the Mn-Mn scattering path was not observed in Mn/NCCl, confirming the existence of atomically dispersed Mn[40]. Additionally, the WT (Wavelet transforms) -EXAFS spectroscopy performs a high response WT signal located at 3.3 Å −1, resulting from the Mn-O contribution (Fig. 2f). While the signal derived from the Mn-Mn contribution is not detected, which further verifies the atomically dispersed Mn in Mn/NCCl (Fig. 2f). Moreover, the coordination configuration of Mn atom in Mn/NCCl was quantitatively analyzed by the EXAFS curve fittings (Fig. 2e). As shown in Fig. 2e and Table S3, the best fitting analyses indicate that the coordination number of Mn-O is 4 with an Mn-O mean bond distance of 1.7 Å[30]. Overall, the above results demonstrate that the Mn atom in Mn/NCCl is anchored by four O atoms, differing from the Mn SACs (coordinated with N atoms) reported in the literature, which may result in the distinct CO2RR performance. Electrocatalytic performance for CO2RR. The electrochemical CO2RR performances were investigated in CO2-saturated 0.5 M KHCO3 solution using a typical H-type cell with a standard three-electrode system. For Mn/NCCl catalyst, the linear sweep voltammetry (LSV) curve delivers lower current density and higher overpotentials under Ar atmosphere than those under CO2 atmosphere, indicating that the CO2RR occurs on the cathode (Fig. S6). For comparison, Mn/NC and NC were also synthesized and measured. As shown in Fig. 3a , Mn/NCCl shows the highest current density among all catalysts, suggesting its best electrochemical CO2RR activity. To further investigate the reduction products selectivity, controlled potential electrolysis of CO2RR was conducted at different potentials. Gas- and liquid-phase products were analyzed by gas chromatography (GC) and nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR), respectively. As illustrated in Fig. S7, CO was obtained as the only carbonaceous product and H2 was the sole byproduct. And no liquid products were detected (Fig. S8). For the Mn/NCCl catalyst, the formation of CO began at a cathodic potential of −0.23 V vs RHE with 65 % of FECO and 4.0 mA cm−2 of j CO. And the FECO increased to 98.5 % at −0.43 V vs RHE with j CO of 9.77 mA cm−2 accompanied with the decrease of H2 FE (Fig. 3b and 3c). However, the maximum CO FE of Mn/NC and NC were only 81.2 % and 55.3 %, respectively (Fig. 3b). Moreover, the Mn/NCCl showed the much lower H2 FE than Mn/NC and NC at all applied potentials (Fig. 3b). In addition, the Mn/NCCl exhibited a maximum CO partial current density of 12.97 mA cm−2 at −0.63 V vs RHE, which is much higher than that of Mn/NC (9.75 mA cm−2 at −0.63 V vs RHE) and NC (2.57 mA cm−2 at −0.53 V vs RHE) in the CO2-saturated 0.5 M KHCO3 solution (Fig. 3c). These results suggested that the high FECO and current density of Mn/NCCl in CO2RR originated from the oxygen atom coordinated Mn in the N adopted carbon framework and the 2D irregular layered sheet structure. The CO2RR activity over the Mn/NC-F, Mn/NC-Br and Mn/NC-I were also measured. Compared to the CO2RR activity of Mn/NCCl, the Mn/NC-F, Mn/NC-Br and Mn/NC-I showed the much lower CO FE of 40.1 %, 81.2 % and 38.5 %, respectively, which also confirms the morphology of Mn/NC-X strongly influenced the activity of CO2RR (Figs. S9 and S10) and the Mn/NC-X with a 2D irregular layered sheet structure shows much higher activity for CO2-to-CO. In addition, the ECSAs (electrochemical active surface areas) for the catalysts play a significant role in the activity of CO2RR. Then, the electric double-layer capacitances (C dl) based on cyclic voltammetry (CV) were conducted to evaluate the ECSAs of Mn/NC(Cl), Mn-NC and NC (Figs. S11 and S12). And the ECSA of Mn/NCCl (35.42 cm2 ECSA) is roughly 1.83 and 11.32 times higher than that for Mn/NC (19.26 cm2 ECSA) and NC (3.13 cm2 ECSA), respectively. It demonstrated that the Mn/NCCl could afford more accessible surface during the electrolytic process owing to the surface enriched O atoms coordinated Mn sites and amorphous layered sheet structure, which synergistically enhances the catalytic activity for CO2-to-CO. According to the Nyquist plots measured under the open circuit potential, the Mn/NCCl shows an arc with a smaller radius than the other catalysts, suggesting its weaker interfacial charge-transfer resistance during CO2RR process (Fig. 3d). Science durability is one of the most important criteria for evaluating the efficiency of catalyst, a 7 h electrolysis CO2RR experiment was conducted over Mn/NCCl in 0.5 M KHCO3 electrolyte. As a result, there was no obvious decline in both current density and FECO (Fig. 3e), which indicated its excellent stability during CO2RR. As known, ionic liquids (ILs) exhibit many unique advantages in electrocatalytic CO2 reduction, including the wide electrochemical potential window, high intrinsic ionic conductivity and large CO2 absorption capacity[41–44]. To investigate the effect of electrolytes, the performance of Mn/NCCl was measured in the CO2-saturated IL electrolyte (30 wt% [Bmim][BF4], 65 wt% CH3CN, and 5 wt% H2O). As shown in Fig. 3f, the Mn/NCCl exhibited a high FECO of 93.8 % at −0.63 V vs RHE with the current density of 27.8 mA cm−2, which is better than that of Mn/NCCl in the 0.5 M KHCO3 electrolyte. Moreover, the Mn/NCCl maintained FECO>90 % at a wide potential range of −0.63 V - 0.73 V vs RHE. The enhanced activity of Mn/NCCl in the IL electrolyte is probably attributed to the higher CO2 solubility in [BMIm][BF4] than that in the KHCO3, leading to the weaker resistance of mass transport on the CO2RR and lower activation energy for the CO2RR process resulting from the increased CO2 adsorption capacity at the cathode via [BMIm-CO2]+. These results indicate that the IL plays a significant role in enhancing the performance of catalysts, especially in the current density and the overpotential. DFT calculations and mechanism of electrochemical CO2RR. DFT calculations were conducted to investigate the inherent activity and property of the Mn/NCCl catalyst. Based on the EXAFS, XPS results and reported studies[30,31,45], two catalysts models with Mn-O4 and Mn-N4 sites were constructed, respectively. All the computational structure models and the detailed data are provided in the supporting information (Figs. S13-S15, Tables S3 and S4). As shown in Fig. S13, the average Mn-O bond length and the coordination number of Mn/NCCl agrees well with the EXAFS results, confirming that the structure of Mn/NCCl is noticeably distinct from the reported N-coordinated Mn SACs (Mn-N3 C3N4/CNT and Mn-N4-G). In addition, the simulations of CO2-to-CO conversion were performed by the well-accepted mechanism with the *COOH intermediate, which is the initial reduction barrier. As shown in the Figs. S14 and S15, the structures of COOH* and CO* intermediates on the surface of these catalysts are provided, and the Mn-O4/G shows a much higher adsorption energy of COOH* (ΔE ads = −1.05 eV) than Mn-N4/G (ΔE ads = −0.27 eV), revealing that the COOH* is more stable on Mn-O4/G than Mn-N4/G (Table S4). Furthermore, the free energy results plotted in Fig. 4 show that the Mn-N4/G (0.13 eV) presents a much higher Gibbs free energy for the formation COOH* than that of Mn-O4/G (−0.62 eV). These DFT calculation results indicate that the Mn-O4/G is beneficial for lowering the overpotential of CO2RR, which is consistent with the experimental results. Conclusion In summary, a nonnitrogen coordinated Mn SAC with a Mn-O4 active site supported on N-doped graphene was successfully synthesized. The synthesized single-atom Mn catalyst exhibited a FECO of 98.5 % at a low overpotential of 0.32 V with a high j CO of 9.77 mA cm−2 in aqueous electrolyte, which outperforms all the reported nitrogen coordinated Mn SACs. Specifically, a higher current density of 27.8 mA cm−2 with a 93.8 % of FECO could be obtained in IL electrolyte. DFT calculations demonstrate that as the active center, the Mn-O4 site is more conductive to the binding of CO2 and favors *COOH intermediate with lower Gibbs free energy compared to the conventional N atoms coordinated Mn SACs. We anticipated that single atom catalyst with nonnitrogen coordination environments may also deliver excellent performance in other valuable electrochemical reactions. coredata.dc:description: Modulating the ordinary nitrogen coordination environment of single-atom catalysts (SACs) is a promising strategy for customizing their activity and selectivity in electrochemical reduction of CO2 (CO2RR). However, less attention has been paid to developing Mn-SACs with nitrogen-free coordination environment for CO2 electroreduction. Herein, we construct a Mn SAC with a coordination structure of Mn-O4 anchored in nitrogen-doped graphitic carbon, which exhibits a 98.5 % of CO faradic efficiency (FECO) with a high CO partial current density (j CO) of ∼9.77 mA cm−2 at a low overpotential of 0.32 V in an H-type electrolytic cell. Furthermore, a higher current density of 27.8 mA cm−2 with a FECO of 93.8 % at 0.51 V overpotential was achieved in an ionic liquid (IL) electrolyte. Density functional theory (DFT) calculations reveal that the Mn-O4 site significantly lowers the free energy of the COOH* formation compared to the conventional N atoms coordinated Mn SACs, and thus facilitates the CO2-to-CO conversion.
coredata.dc:title: Non-nitrogen Mn-O4 coordination environment boosting CO2 electroreduction over single-atom Mn catalyst at low overpotential
